#Text=Prune Dracaena
#Text=There are over 40 types of dracaena species , and you can easily prune all of them with a pair of garden shears and a few snips !
#Text=While pruning is not required , it is fun and gives you control over the shape of the plant .
#Text=You can trim the leaves and stems to keep the plant shorter and bushier if you 'd like .
#Text=To do this , prune your plants in the early spring and late summer , and always use clean and sharp pruning shears .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Pruning Strategically
#Text=Prune your plants in the spring before they hit the growth period .
#Text=From April to May , your dracaena plant comes out of rest mode and gets ready to go into the blooming season .
#Text=Pruning your plants before they hit the growth period keeps them healthy .
#Text=This also makes it easier to shape the plants into your ideal look .
#Text=While you can prune your dracaena whenever you 'd like , this helps encourage new , healthy growth .
#Text=Prune them again in the late summer after their growth period is over .
#Text=Remove leaves and/or stems again in late August after the growth period is over .
#Text=From fall to winter , your plants are in rest mode , where they do not produce leaves and grow larger .
#Text=To help the plant conserve energy , remove long leaves or stems before the rest period .
#Text=This way , your plants can conserve nutrients and stay healthy during the colder months .
#Text=Use a clean , sharp knife or garden shears when pruning your dracaena .
#Text=Always use a sharp blade or pruning shears when pruning your plants .
#Text=If you use a dull blade , this can hurt the plant and make it more challenging for it to heal .
#Text=Before you make your cuts , wipe down your garden shears with rubbing alcohol or an all-purpose disinfectant .
#Text=Using a dirty blade can spread infection and disease .
#Text=This keeps your plants healthy in between prunings .
#Text=Alternatively , you can use a pair of gardening scissors .
#Text=Trimming the Leaves
#Text=Peel off any brown or yellow areas on the leaves using your hands .
#Text=If you notice any unhealthy leaves , you can simply remove them with your fingers .
#Text=Rip the leaves where the discoloration starts so only the green areas remain .
#Text=Look around the entirety of your plants and remove any discolored areas .
#Text=Use gardening scissors instead of your fingers if it is easier for you .
#Text=This keeps your plants looking great and reduces the risk of disease .
#Text=Cut your leaves to resemble the others if you want a uniform look .
#Text=If you want your leaves to look polished and symmetrical , cut your leaves at an angle .
#Text=Follow the shape of the other uncut leaves to make your leaves look realistic .
#Text=This way , you ca n't even notice the leaves were trimmed !
#Text=Snip off any damaged leaves growing out of the base of the cane .
#Text=The cane refers to the stem of the plant .
#Text=Use your fingers to separate the leaf from the cane , and use a pair of gardening scissors to cut off the leaf .
#Text=Do this for any brown or wilted leaves you find .
#Text=Make your cuts as close to the cane as you can .
#Text=Cutting the Stem
#Text=Remove a stem if it 's growing out of form or to encourage upper growth .
#Text=Oftentimes , dracaena species have 1 main stem and a few additional stems .
#Text=If one of the stems grows out to the side and looks unattractive , cut the stem off using your pruning shears .
#Text=You can either cut it at the base of the plant to remove the entire stem , or cut the stem to your desired height .
#Text=The stem will grow a new branch at its new height .
#Text=While this is optional , it will keep your plants looking neat and compact .
#Text=Cut the top of the main stem to create a compact , bushy shape .
#Text=If you want a small , round dracaena plant , use your pruning shears to cut off just the top of the stem .
#Text=Make your cut based on your desired height , though it can be between ¼ to ¾ of the total stem length .
#Text=This encourages new branches to grow near the new top of the stem .
#Text=Avoid cutting your stem if you want a full , wild appearance . Keep in mind that pruning is optional with dracaena plants .
#Text=If you want your plants to look full and luscious , let it grow throughout the season and prune it next year if you 'd like .
#Text=Let the stems grow and see where the branches form .
#Text=You have the ability to customize your dracaena .
#Text=However , once your plants reach the ceiling , you may want to at least trim the leaves !
#Text=Make your cut at a 45-degree angle to keep the plant healthy .
#Text=Look at your stem to see its growth direction , and angle your pruning shears so they are at a 45-degree angle at the stem .
#Text=Tighten your shears quickly to make a clean cut .
#Text=This reduces the risk of infection and allows your plants to heal quickly .
#Text=If you want to replant your clippings , cut the stems straight across after making the 45-degree angle cut .
#Text=Cut your stem to your desired height .
#Text=Pruning dracaenas is a matter of personal preference .
#Text=You can cut off the entire stem if you want to reduce the total number of branches , or you can cut it half-way if you want to grow a more compact top .
#Text=There is no explicit rules when it comes to pruning dracaena plants .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Pruning shears
#Text=Gardening scissors
#Text=Rubbing alcohol
#Text=Tips
#Text=Dracaena is an easy to care for plant that is very resilient and tough .
#Text=Do n't be afraid to prune away its leaves or stem !
#Text=Dracaena are also known as “ corn plants ” or “ dragon trees . ”
#Text=After you trim your leaves and cut your stems , place them in a vase of water if you want to replant them .
#Text=Then , plant them with the mother plant or give them away to a friend .
#Text=In addition , you can through your clippings into a compost bin .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=The dracaena plant is toxic to dogs and cats .
#Text=Quick Summary
